captions.text: kristia rachmawati asks
I'm just curious
one of my Korean friends told me style is a very important there
and especially for the foreigners to be able to fit in
As for you two guys, has there anything changed in you since you moved to Korea
that would never happened if you lived in Canada?
Hmmmm... Complicated question
So we're going to break this apart into just two parts
Did we changed
and is there any pressure for foreigners to change to fit in style wise
Korean women always makes an effort to look good
even if they are grocery shopping or students
They always look really did up
I know, some people will think this as a really negative part of Korean society
but as an average normal person,
come to school wearing really beautiful nice dresses
or ruffles or have their hair little permed with curls
I was wearing my T-shirts and my jeans that I normally wear
I thought, I can't pull off that look
I can't do it, it doesn't fit me
I'm so scared...should I buy this? I don't know
I see my co-teacher is wearing this, I'm not sure if I can do myself
Oh..! I remember that they, you came from work
the most scarring, traumatizing day of my life
There was a co-teacher in my school
and she came to school, she had her dress puffing up
and her hands like this and her palms were opened like this
She was walking all day like this, and I was like
She's really pulling off this really cute, dressy girly looky thing
CUTE THINGS
I'M NOT CUTE ENOUGH FOR YOU
Anyways, that one dress inspired me to move on
The biggest change with you was that you actually wear makeup now
while in Canada you never wore makeup whatsoever
You were pretty much anti-makeup when you were back in Canada
Yah, I was pretty anti-makeup
Hey, Martina you should do makeup tutorial because I don't know what i'm doing
I think Korea changed me in a sense of what I wanna be more feminine
I want to embrace my femininity, if you will my Junsu sexuality
You   your femininity with Junsu sexuality?
No, I'm just saying that Junsu is embracing his sexuality....RUN FOR IT!!!
Now, it wasn't a negative pressure, actually Korea has the opposite affect on foreigners
I never had been so complimented in my whole entire life
but after saying a lot of compliments, I thought
YEAH!! I CAN DO IT!!!
YOU CAN DO THIS!!
I CAN WEAR SOME CUTE BOZEIS!
People thought I was a super model and I was just thinking like,
whooohw!!
You are a supermodel in my eyes
Ah...in your eye I am
but in Cananda, I AM NOT!
I think you're really pretty
Thanks ducky, I think we should get married
Do you wanna get married and have little fuzzy puppies?
Let's do that!
Let's get a cat too!
And let's name it Dr.Meemersworth
PLAN..
When it came to like crazy pink hair and crazy accessories and stuff
You're not wearing any earrings in this video??
OMG!!!!
What are you even doing?
I don't know what happened...
And that's more like it
HAHAHA I had earrings this whole time
yes...
I felt so naked...
Anyways, weird accessories and weird hair stuff like that has always been my style
but it was more like a rock punky kinda gothic look, right?
As a positive thing, not a negative thing I decided
If they can do it, I can do it
I'm gonna make an effort
Now, I feel like I can pull off dresses
But I don't still perk my eyebrows, that was an extra detail
but now, here I am with my makeups on and hair did!
As for me, I was actually inspired by Korean fashion because
Korean guys dress so well,
SO....GOOOD!
I thought to myself, Yeah wanna wear this stuff as well
but the problem is that I'm too big for this country
to fit in anything stylish and whenever I try to put on a sweater
I just never fit, so I thought to myself..
What's the point....What's the point going to out
But although the sexy Korea belly shirt looks good on you
Whooh~ yah belly shirts
That's an actual shirt that I own
Anyhow, now fortune enough when I go back to Cananda once in awhile
I go with an empty suit case and fill it up with much fashionable clothing as possible
and when your manly European burns through those
then throw them to the garbage and buy new ones
THE POWER OF STINK THROUGH CLOTHING!!
That is now a power to be proud of
Why not?
Now for the second part of the question
It's true that style is very important to Korean people
but we don't think it's true that foreigners has to be stylish in order to fit in
I would disagree with that
because no matter how stylish you are, no matter how fluent you are in Korean
you'll always viewed as an outsider
Even if you are wearing the exact same outfit from another Korean girl or another Korean guy
you'll always have foreigner status attached to you
And I would always say that foreign statue gives you more freedom
because a lot of Korean friends of mine says
I wish I could dye my hair like Simon or
I could I have pink hair
I'm like...Why don't you?
They'll like, "Korean society won't accept me"
But you could do it! You're a foreigner
Yah, if I've done my hair in pink, I'm knew as the funky and cool
and can wear low cut short or I could wear more exposed shoulders
I've just realized that I'm not showing lots of chest in this TL;DR also
We can fix that
Hey, easy this is PG audience
Is it?
To us, I think Korean pressure people to fit in to Korean society
To be stylish is different from the one for foreigner to fit than to be stylish
So that's it for this week's TL;DR
If you have a question for next TL;DR,
leave your question on the comment below
or check out the question that are already asked and you could thumb them up if you like them
and perhaps if it comes to our attention we'll might just choose it
And don't forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs

title: Do Foreigners Have to Be Fashionable in Korea?

comments.text:
My friend and I live in the poor part of Auckland and we're used to seeing 
people look borderline homeless(dressing nice will get you robbed/harassed) 
You see us and you'll clutch your handbag a little tighter. Jk jk. But 
anyway, we went to study in Central Auckland. We saw every young Asian 
woman looking like they're about to go to a photoshoot and I felt like a 
failure of a young Asian woman. XD They looked so cute! Every day! They 
bother! And I felt insecurities I didn't know existed! (This is just me, 
not everyone reacted like this but yeah I developed a skill of putting on 
eyeliner in 50 seconds flat just to not feel completely ugly.) But 
everytime I went back to our hometown, I feel overdressed for even a smidge 
of makeup and I go back to my old bare face ways ahaha. I think that 
however you are as a person, you will adapt to the social norm. If let's 
say you moved to a city full of people who bother, you will eventually 
bother. For how long? dunno, hasnt ended for me yet. :O Depends where I am 
tbh.﻿

comments.text:
Oh, here in Brazil it's really hard to be cute. I'm a gothic lolita, even 
though not all the time (lifestyle). But I always love to mix kawaii 
elements and gothic elements, or even some pastel goth inspirations (I 
don't like to label myself).

But it's really hard to be stylish at all here! Right now there's being 
some sort of "modinha" (a behaviour or style that's constantly copied and 
it's popular between teenagers) on tomboys. The thing is that they're not 
tomboys for real, you know. They just do it for getting boys' attention, 
and they judge girls that are more feminine to be a jock or arrogant. It's 
so annoying! 

Any brazilian nasties going through the same? ﻿
comments.author: Beatriz C. Pereira (Baby Bat)

comments.text:
I don't think in Brazil we have a standard or a trend of style... You can

style... I do not think there is one... Here you are cute depending on your 
personality, not your looks... I think it is similiar to the whole America 
this subject... But in Europe people are more concerned about their looks...

comments.text:
I live in the Southwest part of Texas. Next door is Juarez, Mexico. It's 
normal to dress up a little and put on make-up before stepping outside. I 
kid you not;even if you're a senior citizen, you still get gusied up before 
going to the store for bread,eggs,or milk. I don't feel normal if I don't 
put on lipstick , eyeliner and earrings. And talk about color!! Anywhere 
else in the USA, if you wear fusia, bougainvillea or vermilion, it would be 
considered too bright or outrageous. But in El Paso, that's just normal and 
so is complimenting someone on an outfit or hairstyle. I guess that's why 
the small Korean community in El Paso fits in so well here as well as the 
clothing shops they open. ﻿

comments.author: Jessica Angela

comments.text:
Hey, just a quick question, seeing as the main body type in most of asian 
countries is that of a small,petite frame, then are foreigners living in 
Korea able to get clothes that they fit in? And what about women with 
bustier chests? Can they find bra's that they can fit into?﻿
comments.author: moonlightfairy91

comments.text:
that's so funny because I didn't start wearing make-up either until I 
studied abroad in Korea as a rising senior in college. Now, I pretty much 
wear it every day haha It's nice to put effort into how I look though 
because it really helped me build my confidence when I started trying. The 
comment about the pressure for Koreans to fit in but not so much foreigners 
was interesting and I noticed that a lot during the two times I've been to 
Korea. I think that's partially due to the fact that in America, where I'm 
from (as well as some other countries) we grow up surrounded by people who 
don't look like us (note: THIS IS NOT ME SAYING ALL KOREANS/ASIANS LOOK 
ALIKE BECAUSE THEY DON'T AND I KNOW THIS SO IF YOU COMMENT ABOUT ME SAYING 
THIS, THIS IS MY PRELIMINARY ACT OF STICKING MY TONGUE OUT TO YOU XP). But 
from an early age, we are exposed to multiple different cultures and races 
and the only way to "conform" or simply live in such a diverse society is 
to accept differences (a good thing, in my opinion). But if you grow up and 
everyone around you is the same race as you, then the mentality of "fitting 
in" - combined with a history where cultural values are heavily influenced 
by Confucian values from the next-door neighbor (China) - may be simply 
more natural. It's easier to accept the foreigners will always be different 
because no matter what, as someone who is 100% of North-Western European 
descent, I am not going to look like I am from Korea. Doesn't mean I can't 
love the country or the culture though :)﻿
comments.author: TakaraMac90

comments.text: what is school like????﻿

comments.text: +Julian L I live in the Bible Belt of Alabama XD
comments.author: MCBabii1992

comments.text:
+MCBabii1992"If I were to change my appearance to look like them...wow I'm 
pretty sure in my town I'd probably get things thrown at me. People would 
avoid me (except for other people, like one or two other people, who shared 
my want to look that way). I would be shunned from the most of society and 
yet it's ok for the stars to look that way for some reason."
Jesus Christ, seriously? Where in America do you live? That's insane.
comments.author: Julian L

comments.text:
Altho kpop stars hav blonde or shocking hair color, the non famous koreans 
still judge u n look at u differently esp the ahjummas n ahjussi.
comments.author: Alma Yena

comments.text:
Because for a Kpop star It's kinda like a uniform or costume and therefore 
acceptable/expected.
comments.author: MissCaraMint

comments.text:
They're probably famous for that very reason: they do the things other 
Koreans wish they could do.

Just like here living the life of a rockstar/gangster/supermodel etc. isn't 
necessarily something you want to tell your mom about, but people still 
admire these things on TV and sure as hell find it all very exciting. 
Striking up controversies is how you get famous just about anywhere, and 
this kind of look is sort of controversial in Korea, so that's my theory 
behind it all.
comments.author: TimeFly

comments.text:
That's a good question but I think it's just like anywhere else. Or at 
least the US. For example, Miley Cyrus can wear whatever she wants, shave 
the sides of her head, Nicki Minaj can do whatever it is she's doing with 
her appearance and all that and people love them and look up to them (not 
everyone likes them but you know what I mean lol). If I were to change my 
appearance to look like them...wow I'm pretty sure in my town I'd probably 
get things thrown at me. People would avoid me (except for other people, 
like one or two other people, who shared my want to look that way). I would 
be shunned from the most of society and yet it's ok for the stars to look 
that way for some reason. I think it's just some kind of fantasy thing. 
They can look certain ways because they live a life that we 
(generalization) consider idealistic and perfect and so their styles can 
reflect whatever fantasy they want us to believe that they live and we 
accept it because it seems almost unreal. I think the same applies there. 
(Of course this is all based off of theory and generalization, none of this 
statement is factual. But it is just my thoughts on why that might be.)
comments.author: MCBabii1992

comments.text: That's actually a really smart question, I would never have thought of it xD

comments.author: latrinenazi

comments.text:
+FriendLondonFriend
Yes, yes they do. Your view probably had an ad before it and so they get 
paid for the ads through being YT partners as this is actually their job 
and it increases their popularity as well. Also, news flash, most things 
are pointless. I don't see you doing anything important either by making a 
bias/jealous comment and neither am I by responding. Also no, I think they 
like South Korea more then Canada in a lot of respects as it's interesting 
and different. South Korea or even Asia in general, has a LOT of really 
awesome innovative things that become norm their first and then later North 
America catches on.

Also, if you've spoken a certain way over 3/4 of your life, you're going to 
want to do that when you can. English is faster spoken and louder. So your 
comment was completely out of the realm in which the video pertains and was 
unneeded and even a little rude. Many people have interest in living in 
South Korea and so these videos are fun, informative and entertaining to 
watch, even more so because Simon and Martina don't "feel" famous and allow 
regular people to feel at ease with their advice and get some understanding 
about what their experiences might be like should they visit or move to 
South Korea. Have a sweet potato milk tea day.

comments.author: OneLove Phia

comments.text:
Honestly I'm not surprised, haha, Korea is such a wonderful country, 
sometimes western cultures influence wrecks the beauty and that unique feel 
to a country. I see where they are coming from, but as a foreigner I still 
adore Korea and want to visit someday :) Hopefully I won't be too badly 
treated by the ahjummas, some are a little scary, haha :D
comments.author: Sabrina M

comments.text:
Depends; I'm Korean but was raised overseas. I'm still knowledgeable of 
Korean culture and such, but a Korean can instantly tell that I wasn't 
raised locally by my accent. It's recently become more acceptable because 
there are a lot more foreign Korean students, but really it all depends on 
how well you act. If you show that you're Korean (example, you respect 
Korean customs) they won't treat you as a foreigner, but they won't treat 
you as a local either
comments.author: Mike Young

comments.text:
That's the thing: a lot of these ahjummas and ahjusshis are kind of 
stereotypical, should I say? They have an intense sense of patriotism and, 
consequently, a lot of them aren't very happy with the Westernisation of 
Korea. That's why some of them don't even like K-pop; they think of it as a 
'betrayal' of their heritage
comments.author: Mike Young

comments.text:
Wow that sucks :/ Considering K-pop idols are always changing their hair 
color and style, I wonder why its still unacceptable for normal people to

comments.author: Sabrina M

comments.text: AHHHRGG yall are so perfect for each other! im so jelly!! :c
comments.author: Victoria Anne

comments.text:
Here's a VERY good example of why foreigners have more freedom than 
Koreans. I had a Korean tutor when I stayed in Korea for a month, and for 
her it was just a part-time job: she was a really hip awesome person who 
was part of an indie band, and so she'd dyed her hair blonde. She told me 
that because she'd dyed her hair, taxi driver ahjusshis and store ahjummas 
absolutely HATED her; they'd accuse her of wanting to be a foreigner, when 
she just wanted to try something new
